title: Northern Nevada calls for public help in updating regional hazard mitigation plan
message:
Northern Nevada is at risk for 13 identified natural and man-made disasters, and local governments work hard to plan for those disasters and practice ways to mitigate the damage.
The Washoe region is currently reviewing and updating its Hazard Mitigation Plan and is seeking the public’s assistance to ensure that the perspectives, needs and ideas of all its residents are considered in the plan.
These actions can include building defensible space around one’s house to protect against wildfire, or having an evacuation plan in place, staying current on vaccines and healthcare to prevent infectious disease.
You can learn preparation and mitigation tools from the experts at a special open house May 18 at 10 a.m. at the Washoe County Administration Complex, 1001 E. 9th Street, Reno.
Local emergency managers will be available to talk about specific hazards that may be a threat to the region.
event_breakdown:
1. Northern Nevada at risk for 13 identified natural and man-made disasters
2. Local governments planning for and mitigating the damage caused by these disasters
3. The Washoe region reviewing and updating its Hazard Mitigation Plan
4. Seeking public assistance to ensure all residents' perspectives, needs, and ideas are considered in the plan
5. Actions that can be taken to mitigate damage, such as building defensible space and having evacuation plans
6. Special open house event on May 18 at the Washoe County Administration Complex, Reno
7. Experts providing preparation and mitigation tools at the open house
8. Local emergency managers available to discuss specific hazards threatening the region.

title: NOAA : Understand Forecast Information
message:
Use the official National Hurricane Center Forecast — their hurricane specialists access a variety of data (models, aircraft, satellite) to make the most accurate forecasts possible.
Know your alerts & the difference between a Watch & WarningIn general, a Watch means impacts are possible; a Warning means impacts are expected or happening.
A Hurricane Warning means hurricane conditions are expected somewhere within the warning area, with tropical-storm-force winds beginning within 36 hours.
A Tropical Storm Watch means tropical storm conditions are possible within the next 48 hours, a Tropical Storm Warning means they are expected somewhere within the warning area.
The National Hurricane Center Forecast Cone shows the probable forecast track of the center of the storm.
event_breakdown:
- The National Hurricane Center Forecast provides the most accurate forecasts using various data sources.
- Understanding the difference between a Watch and Warning for severe weather alerts.
- A Hurricane Warning indicates that hurricane conditions are expected in the warning area within 36 hours.
- A Tropical Storm Watch suggests the possibility of tropical storm conditions within the next 48 hours.
- The National Hurricane Center Forecast Cone illustrates the probable track of the storm's center.

title: See the scope of flooding in East Texas
message:
Sign up for The Brief, The Texas Tribune’s daily newsletter that keeps readers up to speed on the most essential Texas news.
Recommended VideosDuring the storm that hit a large area of Southeast Texas in late April and early May, a few places recorded an extreme amount of rainfall over several days.
Matt Lanza, an energy meteorologist, said a few places recorded more than 5 inches of rain over the course of an hour.
What was exceptional was the river water levels.
This excess water brought significant river flooding in large areas of East Texas.

title: Disease and hunger soar in Latin America after floods and drought , study finds
message:
Hunger and disease are rising in Latin America after a year of record heat, floods and drought, a report by the World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has shown.
Latin America and the Caribbean have experienced some of the worst effects.
Other areas of Central and South America endured unusually fierce heat and prolonged drought.
Combined with drought, this has hurt agricultural production in one of the world’s most important food production regions.
Overall, Latin America has suffered significant calorific losses, the report said.

title: Hurricane Season 2024 : 6 Life - Saving Preparations to Keep Safe From Challenging Weather
message:
The 2024 hurricane season is near in the U.S., and homeowners should prepare for challenging weather conditions and storms.
Strong winds, flooding, mudslides, flash floods, and landslides always pack it.
Staying informed about the latest forecastsStaying updated on weather conditions can caution homeowners of potential storms or hurricanes.
If there is a flooding watch or any advisories, homeowners should check for potential storm impacts, category, or size.
As a result, emergency supplies are considered life-savers in disasters or evacuations.

title: $2 . 7bn plan to protect Miami - Dade from storm surge headed to Congress
message:
A fast-tracked plan to start armoring parts of Miami-Dade County around Biscayne Bay against powerful hurricane storm surge will soon be headed to Congress for authorization.
It also includes millions of dollars to study the effectiveness of reefs, mangroves and other nature-based solutions on shredding storm surge, which will help determine future features.
The revised strategy came after an initial Corps plan that relied heavily on engineered armoring, including towering flood walls and gates, drew criticism in 2018.
“This is about how you can protect an urban community from storm surge.
I just wonder if there’s another way to be protecting the whole community using some of these nature-based solutions," she said.

title: Watch : Floating Vehicles , Submerged Houses In Brazil As Floods Continue To Create Havoc
message:
Torrential rains have devastated the Brazilian state of Rio Grande do Sul, causing floods that have claimed the lives of at least 95 people.
A user on X posted a video stating “The worst floods in 80 years have hit Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil.
Psalm 93 gives us hope.”The worst floods in 80 years have hit Rio Grande do Sol, Brazil.
Brazil's southern state of Rio Grande do Sul has been enduring it's worst flooding in decades.
#Brazil #BrazilFloods pic.twitter.com/M82pINene4— Peter Dynes (@PGDynes) May 7, 2024The Guaíba lake in Porto Alegre, the capital of Rio Grande do Sul, overflowed, flooding the streets.

The revised strategy came after an initial Corps plan that relied heavily on engineered armoring, including towering flood walls and gates, drew criticism in 2018.
“This is about how you can protect an urban community from storm surge.
“Once we model it and we decide together with Miami-Dade County what that tentative selected plan looks like, then we’ve got to do the engineering behind it.

title: Forecast : Lexington under flood watch , more severe weather possible for Kentucky
message:
Multiple Western Kentucky counties along with areas in Illinois, Missouri and Tennessee are under a moderate risk for severe weather in the NWS’ severe weather outlook.
The moderate risk zone is the second highest risk zone in the NWS’ severe weather outlook.
Andy Beshear encouraged everyone to stay up to date on the latest forecast and have a plan for severe weather.
Lexington weather forecast; no damage from overnight stormsVirtually all of Kentucky, including Lexington, is under a flood watch through Thursday morning.
Lexington along with most of the rest of Kentucky is still under an enhanced risk of severe weather for Wednesday.
event_breakdown:
- Multiple Western Kentucky counties, along with areas in Illinois, Missouri, and Tennessee, are under a moderate risk for severe weather according to the NWS' severe weather outlook.

- Andy Beshear encouraged everyone to stay up-to-date on the latest forecast and have a plan for severe weather.
- Lexington, along with most of Kentucky, is under a flood watch through Thursday morning.
- Lexington, along with most of the rest of Kentucky, is still under an enhanced risk of severe weather for Wednesday.

message:
“The results of the source mechanism analysis show that the quake has a thrust fault mechanism,” he added.
The tremors were felt in Badung, Denpasar, Gianyar, Tabanan, Central Lombok, West Lombok, East Lombok, Mataram City, North Lombok, and West Sumbawa with an intensity scale of III MMI.
In the Karangasem area, it was felt at the II MMI intensity scale.
The BMKG also confirmed that the earthquake did not have the potential to trigger a tsunami.

title: City of San Diego could face $100M in damages from flood victim lawsuits – NBC 7 San Diego
message:
For a second time, a Southcrest homeowner is in the process of suing the City of San Diego because of flooding damage to his home.
The San Diego native’s home of nearly 30 years is now gutted because of the severe flooding that hit San Diego in January 2024.
Get San Diego local news, weather forecasts, sports and lifestyle stories to your inbox.
“I love the city of San Diego, but it’s unfortunate the politicians have let part of San Diego look like a third world country.
They're alleging the City of San Diego inadequately maintained its stormwater system, contributing to its failure and flooding.

title: Super - aged Japan now has 9 million vacant homes . And that a problem
message:
“This is a symptom of Japan’s population decline,” said Jeffrey Hall, a lecturer at Kanda University of International Studies in Chiba.
“It’s not really a problem of building too many houses” but “a problem of not having enough people,” he said.
According to figures compiled by the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications, 14% of all residential properties in Japan are vacant.
“When an earthquake or a tsunami occurs, there is a possibility that vacant houses will block evacuation routes as they break down and get destroyed,” he said.
In other rural areas with a high concentration of vacant houses, akiya have stalled development, the professor said.

title: Dozens of cholera cases reported in flood - hit Kenya
message:
Many parts of Kenya have been hit by floods that have destroyed homes and engulfed roads and bridges (LUIS TATO)The United Nations voiced concern on Wednesday after dozens of cases of cholera were reported in flood-stricken Kenya as the death toll from rain-related disasters surpassed 250.
The World Health Organization (WHO) said 44 cases of the disease have been reported in Tana River County in eastern Kenya, one of the areas hardest hit in weeks of destructive rains and flooding.
Cholera is an acute intestinal infection that spreads through contaminated food and water and typically causes severe diarrhoea, vomiting and muscle cramps.
- Death toll rises -The death toll since March has climbed to 257, according to Kenyan government spokesman Isaac Mwaura.
The UN's Jackson warned of a "significant risk" of another drought, according to long-range forecasts.
location: The main location where the main event takes place is **Kenya**, specifically in Tana River County in eastern Kenya, which has been heavily affected by floods and where cases of cholera have been reported.

title: TIMING : Severe storms possible with damaging winds , possible flooding late tonight
message:
The Miami Valley could see another round of severe weather late Wednesday evening.
Areas south of Interstate 70 are under a SLIGHT risk for this evening, according to Storm Center 7 Meteorologist Britley Ritz.
Storms will return mainly after 7 p.m. this evening, Ritz says.
Photo from: Britley Ritz/StaffPhoto from: Britley Ritz/Staff>>Dry start today, severe storms possible late tonight; Cooler this weekend>>Severe Weather: Slight vs Enhanced RiskPhoto from: Britley Ritz/StaffSEVERE THREATS:Once again, all hazards are in place, Ritz states.
Our Storm Center 7 team of meteorologists will continue to track the system ahead of the storms.
location: The main location where the main event takes place is the Miami Valley.

title: Flood - hit Kenya reports dozens of cholera cases
message:
NAIROBI, May 8, 2024 (BSS/AFP) - The United Nations voiced concern on Wednesday after dozens of cases of cholera were reported in flood-stricken Kenya as the death toll from rain-related disasters surpassed 250.
The World Health Organization (WHO) said 44 cases of the disease have been reported in Tana River County in eastern Kenya, one of the areas hardest hit in weeks of destructive rains and flooding.
Cholera is an acute intestinal infection that spreads through contaminated food and water and typically causes severe diarrhoea, vomiting and muscle cramps.
- Death toll rises -The death toll since March has climbed to 257, according to Kenyan government spokesman Isaac Mwaura.
The UN's Jackson warned of a "significant risk" of another drought, according to long-range forecasts.
location: The main location where the main event takes place is **Tana River County, Kenya**.

title: Expert raises new concerns about Maui County ability to respond to upcoming fire season
message:
HONOLULU (HawaiiNewsNow) - As the summer fire season nears, there’s growing concern about Maui County’s ability to respond to new wildfire emergencies.
And in the future the biggest liability for the county,” Clairmont told HNN Investigates.
A response plan “tells everyone, OK, this is my job and this is what I should do.
“That’s why you need senior leaders there.”Going forward, Clairmont says one of the county’s top priorities should be outlining a wildfire response plan, “You need to train people.
Meanwhile, the state admitted at the time of the Lahaina fire it too didn’t have a plan specific to wildfire response.
location: The main location where the main event takes place is **Maui County**, specifically regarding concerns about its ability to respond to wildfire emergencies.

title: New $20M Coverage for California Commercial Property E & S Risks in Wildfire Prone Areas
message:
Wildfire Defense Insurance Services is offering a $20 million excess and surplus commercial property coverage for E&S risks in wildfire prone areas of California.
WDIS offers E&S commercial property insurance with WDSresponse, provided by WDIS’ affiliate partner, Wildfire Defense Systems, a wildfire services provider that specializes in the placement of commercial E&S wildfire risks through retail agents.
Last month, Munich Re Specialty Insurance announced it is offering a FAIR Plan Commercial Wrap, available to commercial insureds in California who seek comprehensive coverage in tandem with their coverage from the FAIR Plan, the state’s insurer of last resort.
Sold through wholesale brokers, the product gives businesses access to coverage for property damage – including water damage, burst pipe coverage and other non-fire perils – that the FAIR plan excludes.
Topics California Catastrophe Natural Disasters Commercial Lines Wildfire Excess Surplus Business Insurance Property
location: The main location where the main event takes place is **California**.

title: Hurricane season is coming . Residents and experts say get insured now
message:
(KPLC) - May 5 through 11 is National Hurricane Preparedness Week in the United States, and here in SWLA, residents are prepping whether it be making sure they have the tools they need down to making sure they’re covered by insurance.
“I‘ve lived here so long now, and I make sure that I’m covered with insurance because if you’re not, then it’s gonna be bad.
People need to get covered to prepare – the hurricanes are coming,” Polk said.
Landry signed several bills earlier today that put further insurance and hurricane protections in place.
Officials and residents alike say, “Prepare now.”Copyright 2024 KPLC.
location: The main location where the main event takes place is **SWLA** (Southwest Louisiana).

title: Floods Displace Thousands in East Africa ; IOM Calls for Sustained Efforts to Address Climate Mobility
message:
Floods Displace Thousands in East Africa; IOM Calls for Sustained Efforts to Address Climate MobilityGeneva/ Nairobi, 8 May – Weeks of heavy rainfall and flooding in the East Africa region has triggered widespread displacement with hundreds of thousands displaced across Burundi, Kenya, Rwanda, Somalia, Ethiopia and Tanzania.
“The unprecedented and devastating flooding has unveiled the harsh realities of climate change, claiming lives and displacing communities.
Africa is highly vulnerable to climate change, despite contributing only about 4 per cent to global greenhouse gas emissions.
As the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) global climate change discussions in Germany draw near this June, set to shape the agenda for the Conference of Parties (COP), it becomes evident that discussions on climate change must now include considerations of human mobility.
Note to EditorsEast African leaders have signed and committed to the Kampala Ministerial Declaration on Migration, Environment and Climate Change, which addresses both the challenges and the opportunities of climate mobility.

title: Akiya houses : Super - aged Japan now has 9 million vacant homes . And that a problem
message:
Abandoned houses are known in Japan as “akiya” – a term that usually refers to derelict residential homes tucked away in rural areas.
“This is a symptom of Japan’s population decline,” said Jeffrey Hall, a lecturer at Kanda University of International Studies in Chiba.
“It’s not really a problem of building too many houses” but “a problem of not having enough people,” he said.
“When an earthquake or a tsunami occurs, there is a possibility that vacant houses will block evacuation routes as they break down and get destroyed,” he said.
In other rural areas with a high concentration of vacant houses, akiya have stalled development, the professor said.

title: Governor Abbott deploys additional resources ahead of West Texas fire threat
message:
AUSTIN, TEXAS – JANUARY 31: Texas Gov.
Greg Abbott listens to reporters during a news conference on January 31, 2023 in Austin, Texas.
Abbott held a meeting and news conference in preparation for the winter storm that is sweeping across portions of Texas.
On Tuesday, Governor Greg Abbott directed the Texas Division of Emergency Management (TDEM) to deploy additional state emergency response resources ahead of increased wildfire danger in the Panhandle and West Texas.
“Following the largest wildfire in our state’s history, Texas stands ready to provide all available resources to assist firefighters and local officials and protect Texas communities,” said Governor Abbott.
location: The main location where the main event takes place is **Austin, Texas**.

title: After deadly Oklahoma tornado , storms bring twisters to the Midwest
message:
Severe storms battered parts of the Midwest on Tuesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes in the region one day after a deadly twister ripped through a small Oklahoma town and killed at least one person.
Forecasters warn that the storms could stretch late into the night as portions of the three states were under a tornado watch.
Getty ImagesEight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, and at least one tornado was spotted in Kansas, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.
The deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa.
3 Forecasters warn that the storms could stretch late into the night as portions of the three states were under a tornado watch.

title: London plans future flood defence as Thames Barrier turns 40
message:
London, May 8 : Flood defence walls through London will need to be half a metre higher in the future to protect against climate change, officials said as they marked the 40th anniversary of the Thames Barrier.
These include raising the flood walls and defences that line the Thames downriver of the barrier by half a metre by 2040 and then by the same amount by 2050, to the west, through central London.
He said of the barrier: "It's like the sleeping giant, it rolls into action, it wakes up when that is needed."
Storms and weeks of heavy rain bringing high river flow down the Thames meant the barrier was closed 50 times in 13 weeks, including 20 closures on consecutive high tides.
If that intense use were to be replicated more frequently, it would not leave time for the maintenance the barrier needs to ensure it works when required.

title: London future flood defences plans as  sleeping giant  Thames Barrier turns 40
message:
The barrier, officially opened by Queen Elizabeth II, on May 8, 1984, and operated by the Environment Agency, was designed to protect London from flooding until 2030, but the “sleeping giant” is now expected to function until 2070.
But with sea levels expected to rise by a metre by 2100 along with increasingly intense storms driven by climate change, officials say greater defences against flooding will be needed in the coming decades.
These include raising the flood walls and defences that line the Thames downriver of the barrier by half a metre by 2040, and then by the same amount by 2050, to the west, through central London.
While the barrier has met the challenge it was designed for – including rising sea levels factored in before climate change was part of the conversation – the winter of 2013/2014 was extremely difficult.
If that intense use were to be replicated more frequently, it would not leave time for the maintenance the barrier needs to ensure it works when required.

title: Midweek Severe Weather Risk
message:
BRYAN, Texas (KBTX) - Severe weather season is well underway, and this week brings yet another chance for storms to the Brazos Valley.
Southeast Texas is included in the Storm Prediction Center’s severe weather outlook for Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday.
While the risk is not overwhelming, we are monitoring the chance to see strong to severe storms each day.
TUESDAY:The northern reaches of the area are included in a level 1 out 5 risk for severe weather.
SPC Outlook Day 2 - Wednesday (kbtx)THURSDAY:Thursday will bring our best chance at seeing severe weather.

title: Neighbors on the west side of Paso Robles encouraged to prepare for fire season
message:
Paso Robles is participating by hosting block parties on the west side of town, an area with high wildfire risk.
City of Paso Robles Fire Captain John Prickett explained the logic behind targeting those neighborhoods with higher risks.
“On our west side of Paso Robles, that’s where we have the biggest threat to the city,” Captain Prickett said.
Captain Prickett said May, however, is when wildfire season typically begins.
Prickett advises Paso Robles residents to take steps to protect their homes from wildfire.

title: Red Cross partners with Mapleton Fire to help Utahns prepare for wildfire season
message:
Red Cross partners with Mapleton Fire to help Utahns prepare for wildfire seasonSALT LAKE CITY, Utah (ABC4 Utah) – It is that time of year, soon temperatures will rise, vegetation will dry, and then fireworks are right around the corner.
The American Red Cross of Utah and their partners at Mapleton Fire Department want to make sure you are aware of what needs to be done to stay safe this wildfire season.
You may have to leave your home quickly to stay safe.
Do you know how to do your part to prevent wildfires and prepare for an evacuation from a fast-moving wildfire?
When a Wildfire breaks the primary duties of the fire department (s) are when they arrive on scene?
event_breakdown:
1. Red Cross partners with Mapleton Fire to help Utahns prepare for wildfire season
2. American Red Cross of Utah and Mapleton Fire Department raise awareness about safety measures during wildfire season
3. Importance of knowing how to prevent wildfires and prepare for evacuation from a fast-moving wildfire emphasized
4. Primary duties of the fire department when responding to a wildfire outbreak discussed

title: 1st tornado emergency on record for Michigan issued
message:
Michigan Governor declares state of emergency in parts of state over tornadoesMichigan Gov.
Gretchen Whitmer has declared a state of emergency in areas of Michigan due to the tornadoes that hit the area Tuesday.
The National Weather Service issued the first tornado emergency on record for Michigan on Tuesday, as severe weather impacted the region.
A tornado emergency was issued for Union City -- marking the first tornado emergency for the state on record, going back to 1999.
Stitt has declared a state of emergency for several counties in the state due to the severe weather.

title: 57 million people in tornado storm zone as giant hail , destructive winds and flash flooding possible
message:
There were at least 21 confirmed tornadoes on Monday across six states -- Tennessee, Iowa, Kansas, Oklahoma, Missouri and Nebraska.
Union City, Michigan, was under a tornado emergency on Tuesday evening, which was the first tornado emergency ever issued within the state of Michigan.
Elsewhere, multiple homes have been damaged in places like Fairhaven, West Virginia; Irondale, Ohio, Charloe, Ohio; and Garland County, Arkansas.
PHOTO: *** BESTPIX *** Oklahoma Town Of Barnsdall Hit By Deadly Tornado (Brandon Bell/Getty Images)There is a flood warning for the Cincinnati, Ohio, area until 10 a.m.
57 million people in tornado storm zone as giant hail, destructive winds and flash flooding possible originally appeared on abcnews.go.com
event_breakdown:
Events in the text:

1. At least 21 confirmed tornadoes occurred across six states (Tennessee, Iowa, Kansas, Oklahoma, Missouri, and Nebraska).
2. Union City, Michigan, experienced its first-ever tornado emergency on Tuesday evening.
3. Multiple homes were damaged in Fairhaven, West Virginia; Irondale, Ohio; Charloe, Ohio; and Garland County, Arkansas.
4. A flood warning is in effect for the Cincinnati, Ohio, area until 10 a.m.
5. The tornado storm zone potentially affects 57 million people, with the threat of giant hail, destructive winds, and flash flooding.

title: Flood Watch issued for central and eastern Kentucky until Thursday morning
message:
LEXINGTON, Ky. (ABC 36 NEWS NOW) – A Flood Watch has been issued for central and eastern Kentucky until 8 a.m. Thursday morning.
The Weather Prediction Center has included south-central Kentucky in a “Moderate Risk” (Red) for flash flooding.
That means that numerous instances of flash flooding are possible in the low-lying creeks/streams and flood prone areas.
There is not only a flash flooding threat, but a Level 3 Severe Risk is out for all of the ABC 36 Viewing Area.
Stay with the ABC 36 Storm Team for more updates throughout the day.
event_breakdown:
- A Flood Watch has been issued for central and eastern Kentucky until 8 a.m. Thursday morning
- The Weather Prediction Center has included south-central Kentucky in a "Moderate Risk" (Red) for flash flooding
- Numerous instances of flash flooding are possible in low-lying creeks/streams and flood-prone areas
- A Level 3 Severe Risk is out for all of the ABC 36 Viewing Area, indicating severe weather conditions
- Stay with the ABC 36 Storm Team for more updates throughout the day

title: U . S . weather : Forecasters warn Midwest after Okla . tornado
message:
OKLAHOMA CITY -Several Midwest states were bracing for dangerous storms Tuesday as tornadoes spun through parts of Michigan, one day after a powerful twister roared through a small Oklahoma town, killing at least one person and destroying dozens of homes.
Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.
A deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa.
The National Weather Service there had warned Monday evening that "a large and life-threatening tornado" was headed toward Barnsdall.
The storms tore through Oklahoma as areas, including Sulphur and Holdenville, were still recovering from a tornado that killed four and left thousands without power late last month.
event_breakdown:
1. Tornadoes spinning through parts of Michigan.
2. A powerful twister roaring through a small Oklahoma town, killing at least one person and destroying dozens of homes.
3. Eight tornadoes in Oklahoma, two each in Kansas, South Dakota, and Iowa, and one each in Nebraska, Missouri, and Tennessee.
4. A deadly tornado that ripped through the town of Barnsdall in Oklahoma.
5. The National Weather Service warning of a large and life-threatening tornado heading towards Barnsdall.
6. Storms tearing through Oklahoma while areas like Sulphur and Holdenville were still recovering from a previous tornado that killed four people and left thousands without power.

title: Midwest to brace for dangerous storms after deadly Oklahoma tornado
message:
Debris and damage from powerful storms that hit Barnsdall, Oklahoma.
Photo / APWeather forecasters warned residents in several Midwest states to brace for dangerous storms, a day after a powerful twister roared through a small Oklahoma town, killing at least one person and destroying dozens of homes.
The powerful storms come amid a wild swing in severe weather across the globe that includes some of the worst flooding in Brazil and a brutal Asian heatwave.
A deadly tornado that touched down on Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa.
Debris and damage from powerful storms that hit Barnsdall, Oklahoma.
location: The main location where the main event takes place is Barnsdall, Oklahoma.

title: After Deadly Oklahoma Tornado , Storms Bring Twisters to the Midwest
message:
DETROIT—Severe storms battered the Midwest on Tuesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes throughout the region a day after a deadly twister ripped through a small Oklahoma town and killed at least one person.
Forecasters warned that the storms could stretch late into the night with the possibility of more twisters and large hail.
Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, while Kansas, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee all saw at least one tornado.
The deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa.
First responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said.

title: 1st tornado emergency on record for Michigan issued
message:
Michigan Governor declares state of emergency in parts of state over tornadoesMichigan Gov.
Gretchen Whitmer has declared a state of emergency in areas of Michigan due to the tornadoes that hit the area Tuesday.
The National Weather Service issued the first tornado emergency on record for Michigan on Tuesday, as severe weather impacted the region.
A tornado emergency was issued for Union City -- marking the first tornado emergency for the state on record, going back to 1999.
Stitt has declared a state of emergency for several counties in the state due to the severe weather.

title: Red Cross volunteers assist in Houston flood recovery efforts
message:
SAN ANTONIO - Relief is on the way to flooded parts of Texas.
On Tuesday, over 20 local members of the Red Cross went out to those areas.
High waters have inundated Houston neighborhoods, flooding homes and roadways.
The Red Cross is working with county leaders and emergency management offices to assess the necessary help and support.
We spoke with organizers who say they are in desperate need of volunteers.

title: After deadly Oklahoma tornado , storms bring twisters to the Midwest
message:
OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) — Severe storms battered parts of the Midwest on Tuesday, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes in the region one day after a deadly twister ripped through a small Oklahoma town and killed at least one person.
Forecasters warn that the storms could stretch late into the night as portions of the three states were under a tornado watch.
Eight of the twisters were in Oklahoma, and at least one tornado was spotted in Kansas, South Dakota, Iowa, Nebraska, Missouri and Tennessee.
The deadly tornado that touched down Monday night in Oklahoma ripped through the 1,000-person town of Barnsdall, about a 40-minute drive north of Tulsa.
First responders rescued about 25 people, including children, from heavily damaged homes where buildings had collapsed on or around them, Kelley said.

title: 3 . 4 - magnitude earthquake strikes Talala town in Gujarat Saurashtra
message:
According to the Gujarat State Disaster Management Authority (GSDMA), the 3.4-magnitude earthquake struck Talala in Saurashtra at 15:18 hours today.
The epicentre of the earthquake was located 12 km north-northeast of Talala in Saurashtra, the GSDMA said.
More details are awaited.

title: 3 . 1 magnitude earthquake strikes Arunachal Pradesh Lower Subansiri | Itanagar News
message:
ITANAGAR: An earthquake measuring 3.1 on the Richter scale struck Arunachal Pradesh's Lower Subansiri on Wednesday morning, according to the National Centre for Seismology (NCS).The tremors occurred at 4:55 am, as reported by the National Center for Seismology (NCS).
The earthquake had a depth of 10 Km.
"Earthquake of Magnitude: 3.1, On: 08/05/2024 04:55:37 IST, Lat: 27.59 N, Long: 93.91 E, Depth: 10 Km, Location: Lower Subansiri, Arunachal Pradesh," read a post on the official handle of the NCS.
location: The main location where the main event takes place is Lower Subansiri, Arunachal Pradesh.

title: Storms battering the Midwest bring tornadoes , hail and strong winds
message:
In southwestern Michigan, two tornadoes blitzed the city of Portage near Kalamazoo, destroying homes and commercial buildings, including a FedEx facility that was ripped apart.
Portions of Illinois, Kentucky and Missouri were also under a tornado watch, according to the National Weather Service.
DETROIT (AP) — Severe storms barreled through the Midwest, unleashing a curtain of heavy rain, gusty winds and tornadoes throughout the region that forecasters warned could stretch into Wednesday morning.
Enter Email Sign UpTuesday’s storms came a day after parts of the central United States were battered by heavy rain, strong winds, hail and twisters.
The twister tossed vehicles, downed power lines and stripped limbs and bark from trees across the town.

title: One of California largest home insurance companies is raising rates by 15 % on average – Santa Cruz Sentinel
message:
It was not immediately clear where in the state homeowners will see the largest increases, which could take effect as soon as June 24.
On average, California homeowners pay $1,452 a year for coverage, according to Bankrate.com, a personal finance website.
California’s insurance rates are tightly regulated and, as a result, far lower than in many other states.
To calm California’s imploding home insurance market, state regulators have embarked on a yearlong overhaul of home insurance rules and pricing.
Initially, Travelers had asked the state to raise homeowners’ rates by an average of 21.7%.

title: Nearly half of all homeowners concerned weather - related events will raise their homeowners insurance rates
message:
articleThe increase in natural disasters isn’t just wreaking havoc on homes, but on homeowners insurance rates as well.
Head to Credible to compare homeowners insurance rates from numerous different companies, all in one place.
From 2018 to 2023, homeowners insurance rates rose 59.9%, Realtor.com reported .
Comparing multiple insurance quotes can potentially save you hundreds of dollars per year on your homeowners insurance rates.
Drivers looking to lower their home insurance rates can use Credible to compare homeowners insurance companies and shop plans in minutes .

title: Jim First Alert Forecast : Cranking up the heat Wednesday ; Isolated strong storms
message:
Isolated thunderstorms may pop up over inland locations from late afternoon into the evening hours.
The weather will be active late week as a strong cold front approaches Thursday into Friday.
Widespread showers, along with scattered strong to severe storms will be possible on Thursday, especially late in the day.
With warm and moist conditions continuing to dominate, we’ll see sufficient energy for a few strong storms, with damaging winds and hail as the primary threats.
Stay tuned to the WITN First Alert Weather App for more on upcoming changes in the weather.

title: Storm assault on Chinese ports a wake - up call for climate risks
message:
As Typhoon Doksuri aimed toward mainland China, major southeast ports were forced to turn away dozens of vessels for days.
The storm — supercharged by the warm July waters of the Pacific — delivered Beijing's worst flooding in more than 50 years, shuttering factories, ruining crops, collapsing homes and displacing tens of thousands of people.
China's losses from natural disasters in July and August stood at an estimated $10 billion.
But that official Chinese damage tally reflected only a fraction of the costs wrought by the typhoon.
Rebuilding flood-hit areas and climate-proofing infrastructure will cost far more — with China issuing 1 trillion yuan ($139 billion) of sovereign bonds to help.
event_breakdown:
- Typhoon Doksuri heading towards mainland China
- Major southeast ports turning away dozens of vessels due to the typhoon
- Beijing experiencing severe flooding as a result of the storm
- Factories being shut down, crops being ruined, homes collapsing, and tens of thousands of people being displaced due to the flooding
- Estimated losses from natural disasters in July and August amounting to $10 billion in China
- The official Chinese damage tally only representing a fraction of the total costs caused by the typhoon
- China issuing 1 trillion yuan ($139 billion) of sovereign bonds to aid in rebuilding flood-hit areas and climate-proofing infrastructure.

title: Fiji : Tropical Cyclone Mal - DREF Operation n° MDRFJ007 - Final Report - Fiji
message:
Description of the EventApproximate date of impactThe Fiji Group was impacted by TC Mal rain and strong winds on the 14-15 Nov as per the Fiji Met Office's anticipated forecast of galeforce winds, heavy rainfall, and coastal hazards.
A low-pressure system emerged at north of the Solomon Islands on 10 November 2023 and intensified into tropical disturbance TD02F on 11 November 2023.
This development prompted the Fiji Meteorological Office to circulate an alert on 12 November anticipating a potential increase into a Category 3 cyclone by 14 November 2023.
Expanding the warning to encompass the entire Fiji Group for a projected impact on 14-15 November 2023, Fiji Met Office highlighted anticipated gale-force winds, heavy rainfall, and coastal hazards.
• Initially the location potentially impacted by the system was the entire Fiji Group: Yasawa, Mamanuca, Lau, Lomaiviti, and eastern Viti Levu.
event_breakdown:
1. TC Mal impacted the Fiji Group with heavy rainfall and strong winds on 14-15 November 2023.
2. A low-pressure system formed north of the Solomon Islands on 10 November 2023.
3. The low-pressure system intensified into tropical disturbance TD02F on 11 November 2023.
4. The Fiji Meteorological Office issued an alert on 12 November, anticipating the potential development of a Category 3 cyclone by 14 November 2023.
5. The warning expanded to cover the entire Fiji Group, including Yasawa, Mamanuca, Lau, Lomaiviti, and eastern Viti Levu.

title: Submit your questions for KPLC 2024 hurricane preparedness series
message:
(KPLC) - As the 2024 hurricane season approaches, KPLC is helping you stay prepared with our annual hurricane series.
This year, we are also answering viewer questions about hurricane season and being prepared for a potential storm.
You can use the form below to submit a question, and one of our meteorologists may answer it on air.
As always, you can find the latest forecast information on our weather page and First Alert Hurricane Center.
Copyright 2024 KPLC.
event_breakdown:

- KPLC is answering viewer questions regarding hurricane season and storm preparedness.
- Viewers can submit their questions through a form, and meteorologists from KPLC may answer them on air.

title: Akiya houses : Super - aged Japan now has 9 million vacant homes . And that a problem
message:
Abandoned houses are known in Japan as “akiya” – a term that usually refers to derelict residential homes tucked away in rural areas.
“This is a symptom of Japan’s population decline,” said Jeffrey Hall, a lecturer at Kanda University of International Studies in Chiba.
“It’s not really a problem of building too many houses” but “a problem of not having enough people,” he said.
“When an earthquake or a tsunami occurs, there is a possibility that vacant houses will block evacuation routes as they break down and get destroyed,” he said.
In other rural areas with a high concentration of vacant houses, akiya have stalled development, the professor said.

title: Bradford Council gives its thoughts on Bank Holiday Monday flooding | Bradford Telegraph and Argus
message:
It added that the major works taking place across the city centre includes more greenery and planting, to help reduce surface run off.
"We are mindful of the increases in extreme weather events, such as flooding, due to climate change.
“New highways schemes like the work taking place as part of the improvements to the city centre are designed in line with national standards for extreme weather events.
“The scheme under construction in the city centre already includes more greenery and planting, to help counter some of the effects of climate change and reduce surface run off.
“The scheme at North Parade in the city centre and the work on North Street in Keighley are two examples of this type of work.

title: London future flood defences plans as  sleeping giant  Thames Barrier turns 40
message:
The barrier, officially opened by Queen Elizabeth II, on May 8, 1984, and operated by the Environment Agency, was designed to protect London from flooding until 2030, but the “sleeping giant” is now expected to function until 2070.
But with sea levels expected to rise by a metre by 2100 along with increasingly intense storms driven by climate change, officials say greater defences against flooding will be needed in the coming decades.
These include raising the flood walls and defences that line the Thames downriver of the barrier by half a metre by 2040, and then by the same amount by 2050, to the west, through central London.
While the barrier has met the challenge it was designed for – including rising sea levels factored in before climate change was part of the conversation – the winter of 2013/2014 was extremely difficult.
If that intense use were to be replicated more frequently, it would not leave time for the maintenance the barrier needs to ensure it works when required.

title: Series of tax - free holidays coming to Florida families ahead of hurricane season
message:
The first preparedness holiday will start June 1, at the start of the hurricane season, while the second will be from Aug. 24 to Sept. 6, just before the peak of the storm season.
"You could have a busy hurricane season and nothing could hit Florida.
You could have a low hurricane season and have one hit us.
"We know that there are many, many predictions for a very active hurricane season.
Let my team worry about the big hurricane season, multiple disasters that may or may not come our way.
event_breakdown:
1. The first preparedness holiday will start on June 1, coinciding with the beginning of the hurricane season.
2. The second preparedness holiday will be from August 24 to September 6, just before the peak of the storm season.
3. There are varied predictions for a very active hurricane season.
4. The possibility exists that despite a busy or low hurricane season, Florida may or may not be impacted by a hurricane.
5. A team is responsible for preparing and monitoring multiple potential disasters during the hurricane season.

title: Fog , coastal flooding and severe weather in NJ forecast
message:
More coastal flooding will threaten Wednesday night, and then we watch for two rounds of strong to severe storms Thursday.
Fog and coastal flooding will return Wednesday night.
The coastal flooding will be around for a few hours between 8 p.m. and 2 a.m.
If we do get that evening line of strong storms, power outages and wind damage will be a real concern.
Southeast winds will mean more coastal flooding at high tide.
event_breakdown:
- More coastal flooding threatens Wednesday night
- Two rounds of strong to severe storms expected on Thursday
- Fog and coastal flooding will return on Wednesday night
- Coastal flooding will occur between 8 p.m. and 2 a.m.
- Power outages and wind damage are possible if strong storms occur in the evening
- Southeast winds will contribute to coastal flooding during high tide.

title: NWS urges preparedness ahead of Tri - State storms
message:
(WFIE) - Those with the National Weather Service say severe storms aren’t quite as isolated to the spring months as they used to be, but people still need to be extra vigilant this time of year.
“Most people that have lived in this region understand that we are in an area that is prone to severe weather,” said National Weather Service Warning Coordination Meteorologist Christine Wielgos.
Recently, places to our west, including Texas, have had storms causing severe flooding, along with tornadoes.
The conditions which could lead to severe weather have been moving east though.
Officials with the National Weather Service say the vast majority of severe weather used to hit in April and May, in recent years it’s been spreading throughout the rest of the year.
event_breakdown:
- National Weather Service warns about the increase in severe storms throughout the year
- Christine Wielgos, National Weather Service Warning Coordination Meteorologist, acknowledges the region's susceptibility to severe weather
- Recent severe storms causing flooding and tornadoes in Texas
- Conditions for severe weather are shifting eastward
- Severe weather previously concentrated in April and May, but now spreading throughout the year

title: Severe storms with tornado threat moving into Metro Detroit
message:
4Warn Weather – A tornado watch has been issued for part of Southeast Michigan, including Washtenaw, Lenawee and Monroe counties until 11 p.m.
Most of Southeast Michigan is under a low risk of strong to severe storms this evening.
Thunderstorms will move into Southeast Michigan during the evening.
That chance will increase over southern portions of Southeast Michigan, particularly south of I-96.
The severe threat for Southeast Michigan should end by 11 p.m., but a few showers and thunderstorms will linger later.
event_breakdown:
- Tornado watch issued for part of Southeast Michigan (including Washtenaw, Lenawee, and Monroe counties) until 11 p.m.
- Low risk of strong to severe storms in most of Southeast Michigan this evening.
- Thunderstorms moving into Southeast Michigan during the evening.
- Increased chance of severe storms in southern portions of Southeast Michigan, especially south of I-96.
- Severe threat for Southeast Michigan expected to end by 11 p.m., with lingering showers and thunderstorms later.

title: Dont fall for these hurricane season misconceptions
message:
Here are some of the most common myths related to hurricane season.
Look into this prior to hurricane season.
Here’s what’s wrong with that: Tropical storms and even tropical depressions can be deadly and destructive.
Meteorologists will talk about how far out tropical storm force or hurricane force winds extend out.
An early start to hurricane season means the season will be bad, and a late start means things will be calm, right?
event_breakdown:
1. Common myths related to hurricane season
2. Research into hurricane season prior to its start
3. Impact of tropical storms and depressions
4. Discussion of the extent of tropical storm and hurricane force winds
5. Misconceptions about the start of hurricane season

title: NWS : Severe weather outbreak likely today in Tri - State
message:
The National Weather Service's expectations for timing of severe thunderstorms in the Tri-State on Wednesday.
Severe thunderstorms are likely in the Tri-State on Wednesday, the National Weather Service said, continuing a run of active weather in the region.
Most of the Ohio Valley is in an "enhanced risk" area for severe weather on Wednesday, which is the third-highest on a five-step scale employed by the Storm Prediction Center.
What kinds of severe weather are possible in the Evansville and Henderson areas?
This article originally appeared on Evansville Courier & Press: NWS: Severe weather outbreak likely today in Tri-State
event_breakdown:
- The National Weather Service predicts severe thunderstorms in the Tri-State region on Wednesday.
- Most of the Ohio Valley, including the Evansville and Henderson areas, is under an "enhanced risk" for severe weather.
- The severe weather outbreak is likely to occur today in the Tri-State, according to the National Weather Service.
